The so-called Marxist Conspiracy of 1987 saw 22 young Catholic social workers arrested by the Internal Security Department (ISD) and accused of plotting to overthrow the PAP. Many of them at that time were involved in helping foreign workers and were advocating workers’ issues like higher pay, better working conditions for foreign workers and job benefits among others. The alleged accusations against them of being Communists were never proven.

This is witnessed most clearly in the numerous speeches of political leaders emphasising on the role of the market in determining the price of public housing, the wages of workers, the rejection of a minimum wage law as well as the astronomical salaries of senior public servants and political leaders.

The CSC consisted of a committee of cabinet ministers, senior civil servants and prominent businessmen in Singapore. It was set up in 1996 to look into ways by which Singapore could enhance its economic competitiveness, and later expanded into recommending measures to help the Singapore economy cope with the 1997 Asian Economic Crisis.
It is stated in the CSC report that ‘the ongoing liberalisation of our [Singapore’s] CPF has been an important catalyst to the fund management industry and should continue’ (CSC, 1998: 136).

Social inequality has been rising over the last decade although it fell slightly in 2009, only to rise again in 2010. The GINI Index for Singapore as of 2010 stands at 0.48 (Department of Statistics [DoS], 2010: 7). This is an increase from 0.478 in 2009 (DoS, 2009: 7) after falling slightly in 2008 from 0.481 (DoS, 2008: 6). The GINI Index for Singapore remains one of the highest amongst developed economies. The decrease of the figure in 2009 was the only stretch of time over the last decade that it fell. The decline was attributed by the DoS to schemes put in place by the state in 2009 that ‘resulted in a reduction in household income disparities’ (DoS, 2009: 8).

The arguments against the minimum wage ranges from the assumption that having it only slows and/or scares away foreign investment from Singapore thereby causing retardation in the growth of the economy to a minimum wage raising the costs of everything, to causing companies to be lose their competitiveness. Former Minister Mentor Lee Kuan Yew’s argument against the minimum wage is typical: ‘[a minimum wage] to narrow the income gap could do more harm than good’ and that ‘every country that has set a minimum wage over what the market will bear has found that the move cuts jobs’ (Au Yong, 2009). Instead, he maintains ‘the market [should be left] to decide the right level of pay’ (Au Yong, 2009). The following statement by the Ministry of Manpower (MOM) also reiterates that rhetoric: ‘Whether wages [for workers] should increase or decrease is best determined by market demand and supply for labour, skills, capabilities and competency to perform the task’ (Hooi, 2004, emphasis added).

While it is beyond the paper to present the case for a minimum wage here, it is highly debatable that a minimum wage necessarily leads to the dismal scenario that Lee Kuan Yew paints above. The allusions to a neutral arbiter in the market is highly flawed as the fact that employers have the power to decide on the wages since workers experience much personal costs when unemployed is unacknowledged. This power is exercised when the employers pay employees what the latter would otherwise earn in a truly competitive market (Chapman, 2004). In fact, ‘there is no demonstrated statistical relationship between high wages and lower employment…[as] employment levels are not determined, primarily in the labour market’ (Stanford, 2008: 156). Rather, the existence of a minimum wage increase (or in Singapore’s case, actually having a minimum wage) will ‘correct a market imbalance by forcing employers to pay a fair wage’ (Chapman, 2004). See also Institutional Economics and the Minimum Wage: Broadening the Theoretical and Policy Debate (Kaufman, 2010) for an updated analysis on the minimum wage debate.

The argument by the PAP is that there is a need to pay an astronomical salary pegged at “market rates” i.e. what the individual would otherwise be getting in the private sector had he or she be in a similar type of position. The rationale is so that “top” talent will be attracted to serve in the public sector. It is never asked if these individuals been in the private sector, would they have been able to rise to the equivalent of the public sector positions that they are holding in the first place.

In the communications sector for instance, the market is dominated by three companies – SingTel, StarHub and MobileOne (M1). As of 2010, Temasek Holdings has substantial shares in all three companies, in particular the former two.

Mitchell (1991) also discusses the notion of the state but as a structural effect. He uses the example of the reorganising of the army in the eighteenth century; one could observe the ‘effect produced by the organised partitioning of space, the regular distribution of bodies, exact timing, the coordination of movement, the combining of elements, and endless repetition, all of which are particular practices’ (Mitchell 1991: 93-4). However, it is in the ‘order and precision of such processes [that] created the effect of an apparatus apart from the men themselves, whose structure orders, contains, and controls them’ (Mitchell 1991: 94). It is this that needs to be taken note of vis-à-vis the state, as it is to be analysed ‘as the powerful, metaphysical effect of practises that make such structures appear to exist’ (Mitchell 1991: 94). Such an arrangement allows for one to ‘both acknowledge the power of the political arrangements that we call the state and at the same time account for their elusiveness’ (Mitchell 1991: 94-5). There is a distinct parallel of Mitchell’s to Lemke’s (and hence Foucault’s) approach – the power of political arrangements can arguably be the sort of power relations and strategies that the latter discusses (See Mitchell, 1991).

It is useful to note that the advent of the internet and the concomitant widespread usage of new media technologies such as blogs and podcasting mean that the use of outright state coercion can no longer be carried out (as it was done during the so-called Marxist Conspiracy) without its actions becoming widely known globally. Suppression or restricting the internet would also not be possible since a key aspect of its economic strategy involves making use of IT ‘as a business enabler’ (CSC, 1998: 103), with e-commerce as a major component (CSC, 1998: 104). Consequently, its aspirations at becoming a global city and attracting the global elite to move to Singapore among other goals mean that state coercion must now be exercised with the knowledge that its actions will have greater repercussions than previously. Again, this does not mean that the state will back away from the use of coercion, only that they might be more subtle and circumspect as to how they go about doing it.

It is possible that the basis of such a policy has its foundations in eugenics. It is well known that Lee Kuan Yew believed in eugenics. Thus, high IQ levels to him are unevenly distributed across the different “races” of Chinese, Malay, Indian and “Others”. In one instance, he compares the mathematical ability of the Chinese and the Malay as inherent and different between each “race”:

‘“The first thing is we bring the problems out into the open,” [Lee Kuan Yew] replied. “If you pretend that the problem doesn’t exist, and that in fact [the Malays] can score as well as the Chinese in mathematics, then you have created yourself an enormous myth which you will be stuck with. And there will be such great disillusionment”’ (Richardson, 1992).

The above statement was made in the context that of him saying that there are ‘differences in learning aptitude between blacks, whites and other races in America’ (Richardson, 1992), and the situation of the blacks in the United States parallel that of the Malays in Singapore.

Lee also believes that high IQ is more predominant amongst those in the upper class, as seen for instance, in the attempt to introduce the Graduate Mothers’ Scheme in 1983. This extremely unpopular scheme has a eugenics basis. Its purpose was to encourage university graduates who presumably had higher Intelligence Quotient (IQ) levels to produce babies through a whole host of incentives, thereby improving the gene pool of the population. Although ultimately abandoned, the scheme made prominent the use of biopower to govern the population. It emphasises that the PAP had consistently intervened in the lives of Singaporeans, and continues to do so even until the present day. As Lee himself states,

‘And I say without the slightest remorse, that we wouldn’t be here, we would not have made economic progress, if we had not intervened on very personal matters - who your neighbour is, how you live, the noise you make, how you spit, or what language you use. We decide what is right. Never mind what the people think’ (Katigbak, 1990).
In light of the above, it is not unreasonable to extend the same line of thinking within the PAP-dominated government to the management of the types of migrant workers coming in.

The other major technology of subjectivity that the PAP utilises is known as the Workfare Income Supplement (WIS) Scheme or Workfare. Introduced in 2007, Workfare is a cash payment to old and low-wage Singaporean workers i.e. earning less than SGD 1500 a month. Other criteria applies as well, including length of time worked (at least 3 months out of a 6-month period), living on a property that has an Annual Value of less than SGD 11,000 and be at least 35 years old and above. In 2010, the scheme was revised with the increasing of the limit to SGD 1,700 instead. In addition, there is the introduction of a Workfare Training Support Scheme, which combines labour upgrading with the workfare scheme. Consequently, receiving aid from the state is conditional upon being part of the labour force. The implication here suggests that only those who are working merits any form of help. Rather than citizenship, the basis of aid is contingent upon their economic participation that will deem them as worthy of aid. Workfare thus puts across and emphasises the notion that by and large, the individual is to be responsible for his or her own welfare, even if that individual in question is an elderly. Assistance from the state cannot be counted upon – one needs to work for the aid.
For instance, in the National Day Rally Speech of 2009, the Prime Minister (PM) Lee cited the example of a Mr Mohd Amin:

‘After the retrenchment, I feared I can’t find another job because of my age… The career centre coached me to learn a skill and start a new career path. I felt supported… ‘I attended the job placement event and I successfully found a job as an Enforcement Specialist. The training allowed me to do my job confidently. ‘I’m doing well. I am so happy now as I am earning more than before’ (Lee, 2009).

PM Lee then stressed this point made by Mohd Amin: ‘I will ask my friends to go to career centre for support and help. Tell them to be flexible and not choosy.’ The message that the PM is trying to convey vis-à-vis the issue of retrenchment cannot be clearer.
